questionParts: Let \(f(x, y) = x^2 - y^2\) and suppose we move from the point \((1,1)\) in the direction of the unit vector \(\vec{u} = \left\langle \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} \right\rangle\).
What is the directional derivative \(D_{\vec{u}}f(1,1)\) in that direction?
explanationParts: First, compute the gradient of \(f\): \(\nabla f(x, y) = \langle 2x, -2y \rangle\).
At the point \((1, 1)\), we have \(\nabla f(1, 1) = \langle 2, -2 \rangle\).
The directional derivative is the dot product: \(D_{\vec{u}}f(1,1) = \nabla f(1,1) \cdot \vec{u}\).
